chapter.title: 002-第二回-張翼德怒鞭督郵，何國舅謀誅宦豎

chapter_pov_notes: Liu Bei anchors frontline continuity and witnesses Guan Yu/Zhang Fei plus campaign outcomes; He Jin anchors court intrigue with Emperor Ling, Empress He, Zhang Rang, and Jian Shuo. This pairing minimizes overlap while covering military and political threads.

Liu Bei.A:
1) [narrative] Zhu Jun camp: Liu Bei, Guan Yu, and Zhang Fei join Zhu Jun after leaving Dong Zhuo's command; strategy is set against Zhang Bao.
2) [battle] Mountain-front / Yangcheng approach: Liu Bei engages Zhang Bao, is forced back by sorcery, then executes the blood-and-filth counterplan with Guan Yu and Zhang Fei, routs the rebels, wounds Zhang Bao, and begins the Yangcheng pressure.
3) [battle] Wan city campaign: Liu Bei fights through Han Zhong, Zhao Hong, and Sun Zhong operations around Wan, argues for opening an escape lane to avoid desperate last-stand resistance, and helps secure victory.
4) [map] Courtward transition: After battlefield success but delayed promotion, Liu Bei transitions from campaign front to civil post assignment at Anxi.
5) [narrative] Anxi county office: Liu Bei governs cleanly, faces extortion by the inspector (督郵), then after Zhang Fei's intervention chooses to resign rather than submit to corruption.
6) [map] Flight and redeployment: Liu Bei leaves with Guan Yu and Zhang Fei, shelters under Liu Hui, then redeploys north under Liu Yu against Zhang Ju and Zhang Chun.
7) [battle] Youzhou/Yuyang suppression: Liu Bei contributes to anti-rebel operations that end the northern uprising.
8) [narrative] Post-campaign restoration: Liu Bei's offense is pardoned and he returns to office at lower rank, ending the chapter reset but still ascending through merit.

C.en: Liu Bei leaves Dong Zhuo and joins Zhu Jun against the Yellow Turbans. Victories at Yangcheng and Wan bring fame, but office brings corruption.
C.zh: 刘备离开董卓后投朱儁，转战讨黄巾。阳城、宛城连战扬名后，他入仕却立刻直面贪腐与权贵压迫。

He Jin.A:
1) Audience halls and inner court succession crisis - [narrative] Emperor Ling falls gravely ill, and He Jin becomes the key military power behind the throne through his position and his tie to Empress He. Jian Shuo and allied eunuchs attempt to control succession by isolating He Jin and elevating a rival line, but He Jin survives the trap and regains initiative at court.
2) He Jin's headquarters and ministerial councils - [narrative] With open trust between civil officials and eunuchs broken, He Jin consults Yuan Shao, Cao Cao, and other advisers on how to purge the Ten Attendants. He Jin repeatedly hesitates between decisive action and palace compromise, showing both his formal authority and his political uncertainty.
3) Capital approaches and provincial mustering routes - [map] To pressure the palace faction, He Jin authorizes calls for outside commanders and troops to move toward Luoyang. This geographic escalation shifts the conflict from closed-court intrigue toward a wider military-political confrontation.
4) Palace decision chamber before the strike - [narrative] He Jin settles on a final anti-eunuch course, framing the move as restoration of imperial order rather than personal vendetta. The chapter leaves him at the brink of execution, with all factions armed and waiting for the next misstep.

C.en: As Emperor Ling falters, He Jin becomes the court's military pillar. Between eunuch plots and hesitant allies, he weighs delay against a purge.
C.zh: 灵帝病危，何进成为朝廷军权中枢。宦官暗算与同僚迟疑交错之下，他在拖延与清洗之间作出危险抉择。
